definitions:
(transitive) to take, hold, pick up, get
gli studenti prendono appuntithe students take notes
prese la fidanzata e la avvicinò a séhe took his girlfriend and brought her closer to him
prendere la paga ― to take the paycheck
(transitive) (of a political territory or entity) to conquer

(transitive) to take (a means of transport)
prendere il treno ― to take the train

(transitive, by extension) to choose (a certain route or path)
prendere la scorciatoia ― to take the shortcut

(transitive) to catch (a criminal, animal, etc.)
prendere un latitante ― to catch a fugitive
prendere una lepre ― to catch a hare

(transitive, by extension) to catch (an illness)
prendere un raffreddore ― to catch a cold
(familiar, transitive) to be beat up or defeated
(transitive) to get, buy

(transitive, familiar) to steal
gli hanno preso il telefonothey stole his phone (from him)

(transitive) to assume (a task, responsibility, etc.)
prendere un compito ― to take up a task

(transitive) to hit or strike
prendere il bersaglio ― to hit the target
prendergli una gamba ― to hit his leg

(transitive with a) to hit or strike (with/using)
prendere a calci ― to kick (literally, “to hit with kicks”)
prendere a pugni ― to punch (literally, “to hit with punches”)
(transitive) (of food, drink, medicine, etc.) to eat, drink, ingest

(transitive, familiar) to romantically attract
i suoi occhi mi preseroI fell in love with his eyes(literally, “his eyes attracted me”)

(transitive) to acquire (a characteristic)
il latte ha preso un sapore acidothe milk acquired an acidic taste

(transitive) to pursue (a vocation)
prendere ingegneria ― to pursue engineering

(transitive) to measure
la mamma gli ha preso la temperaturathe mother took his temperature
dobbiamo prendere la lunghezza del percorsowe have to measure the length of the course

(transitive) to pick up, receive (a radio, TV, telegraphic, etc. transmission)
prendere il segnale ― to pick up the signal

(transitive) to feel (an emotion)
prendere corraggio ― to hearten (literally, “feel courage”)
prendere fiducia ― to trust (literally, “feel trust”)
lo prendo in simpatiaI look kindly on him(literally, “I feel him in pleasantness”)

(transitive) (of a sensation, feeling, etc.) to take hold of, seize, or strike (someone)
una terribile paura gli ha presoa terrible fear struck him

(transitive, familiar) to occupy or take up (space or time)
quel dipinto prende tutto il murothat painting takes up the entire wall

(transitive, familiar, by extension) to occupy someone's mind
è preso dalla matematica ― he is obsessed with math

(transitive) to require (energy, effort, etc.)
un'impresa che prende tutte le vostre energiean undertaking that requires all of your energy
(transitive) (sometimes with per) to take for or confuse

(transitive) to interpret
prendere la legge alla lettera ― to interpret the law to the letter
Synonyms: interpretare, intendere, scegliere, adottare

(transitive) to choose (someone) (for) (a role, job, etc.); to hire
l'hanno preso per bidello ― they hired him as a janitor

(transitive) to treat (someone) (in a certain way)
mi hanno preso a male parolethey insulted me(literally, “treated me with bad words”)

(transitive) to accept
ora si deve prendere la vita come vienenow we have to take life for what it is

(intransitive) (with a or per) to move (towards); to head (for)
prendere a destra ― to turn right

(intransitive) (with a + inf.) to begin
da quel giorno prese ad amarlafrom that day, he began to love her
(intransitive) (of a fire) to begin to burn
(construction, intransitive) (of a binder) to adhere to the building materials by hardening; to take hold
(intransitive) (of a plant) to take root
(intransitive, auxiliary essere) to happen unexpectedly
etymology: From Latin prendere, alternative form of prehendere, present active infinitive of prehendō, from prae- (“before”) + *hendō (“I take, seize”) (not attested without prefix), from Proto-Indo-European *gʰed-.
